A. 
 
2. 
The PRC’s economic growth since the 1980s has substantially increased the demand for 
transport services. The economy’s changing structure and increasing diversification have altered 
the  pattern  of  transport  demand.  The  demand  for  road  transport  has  outpaced  that  of  other 
transport  modes.  There  is  a  rapidly  increasing  movement  of  goods  and  passengers  by  road, 
which is more flexible and responsive than other modes to the needs of a market economy. The 
shift  in  transport  demand  also  reflects  the  loosening  of  anticompetitive  restrictions  in  the  road 
transport  industry  itself.  From  1990  to  2004,  road  traffic  grew  by  9.0%  per  annum  (p.a.)  for 
passenger traffic, reaching 876.5 billion passenger-kilometers (km); and by 6.0% p.a. for freight, 
reaching  759.7  billion  ton-km.  In  Sichuan,  road  traffic  grew  by  6.5%  p.a.  for  passenger  traffic, 
reaching 51.7 billion passenger-km, and by 4.2% p.a. for freight, reaching 27.2 billion ton-km. In 
2004, road traffic accounted for 53.7% of the country’s total passenger traffic and 11.4% of the 
total freight traffic while the corresponding figures for Sichuan Province were 76.0% and 26.3%. 
The  vehicle  fleet  will  continue  to  expand  with  the  country’s  rapid  economic  growth,  low  vehicle 
ownership  rates,  lower  automobile  prices  after  World  Trade  Organization  accession,  increasing 
access  to  loans  to  finance  automobile  purchases,  and  large  investment  in  automotive 
manufacturing. 
 
3. 
To  meet  the  growing  demand  for  improved  transport  infrastructure  and  services,  the 
Government’s policy for the road sector, as reflected in its 10th Five-Year Plan (2001–2005), calls 
for (i) accelerating the construction of the network of highways and national roads, with a focus on 
five north–south and seven east–west sections of the national trunk highway system; (ii) starting 
construction  of  eight  new  highways  for  18,000  km  in  the  western  region;  (iii) by  2005,  opening 
approximately 1.95 million km of highways to traffic, with expressways1 accounting for 35,000 km; 
and  (iv)  starting  the  national  expressway  network  plan  to  complete  85,000  km  by  2040  with 
annual investment of CNY100 billion–150 billion. 
 
4. 
While the national trunk highway system is being developed, accessibility in most of rural 
PRC is still low: 145 townships and 50,124 villages, most in the western region, have no access 
to  all-weather  roads.  Many  townships  and  villages  still  depend  on  earth  tracks  that  are  not 
suitable  for  motorized  traffic  and  become  impassable  during  the  rainy  season.  Even  where  all-
weather roads have been built, the standard of rural roads is low, maintenance is poor, and many 
roads  need  rehabilitation.  The  central  Government  thus  completed  71,000  km  of  rural  roads  at 
the  cost  of  CNY60.9  billion,  supported  by  the  local  governments  that  constructed  68,000  km, 
costing  CNY57.6  billion,  in  2004.  The  Government  targets  developing  a  road  network  that  will 
reach 99.8% of townships by 2005. The Government plans to invest CNY100 billion in developing 
rural  roads  during  the  11th  Five-Year  Plan  (2006–2010).  By  2010,  all  villages  in  the  eastern 
region will be linked with paved roads, and the same targets will be applied to 80% villages in the 
central  region  and  90%  towns  in  the  western  region.  In  2003,  the  Sichuan  Provincial 
Communications  Department  (SPCD)  prepared  the  Sichuan  Province  Rural  Road  Development

B. 
 
6. 
Sichuan  is  in  southwestern  PRC,  surrounded  by  mountains.  Its  isolation  has  been 
reduced by improved navigation on the Yangtze River, railway construction, and the construction 
of several major highways. Most of the population is concentrated on the flat, fertile plain in the 
east and central east, but the province contains several poverty-stricken areas in its mountainous 
periphery, where the Project is located. Despite rapid development in recent years, Sichuan ranks 
seventh lowest of all provinces in terms of gross domestic product (GDP) per capita: CNY7,514 in 
2004, or 72% of the national average. The per capita rural income was CNY2,580, or 88% of the 
national  average.  About  one  third  of  the  counties  are  officially  designated  as  poor.  There  are 
282,500 poor people in the project area, equivalent to 29% of the total population, living below the 
income levels of CNY900 per year in rural areas and the minimum living standards in urban areas. 
 
7. 
Based on the findings of the feasibility study under an ADB-financed technical assistance 
(TA), 3  one  reason  for  high  poverty  is  slow  economic  growth,  partly  because  of  inadequate 
infrastructure. Despite the considerable investments, the road network in the project area is still 
inadequate and does not provide efficient transport access to markets and social services such 
as  education  and  health.  Around  30%  of  villages  in  Hanyuan  and  Mianning  still  have  no  road 
access. Over the whole project area, over 60% of villages have paved road access but only one 
third have bus services. The proportions in Shimian and Mianning are much lower, with under a 
quarter of villages having paved road access and less than 20% having bus services. In the last 3 
years,  local  governments  have  improved  access  to  13  townships  (10%  of  the  total)  and  29 
villages  (4%).  These  road  improvements  have  led  to  the  provision  of  bus  services  to  these

The impact of road investments on poverty reduction is supported by the results of studies 
and evaluations of several completed road projects financed by ADB4 and the World Bank.5 Well-
integrated  road  development  helps  ensure  that  the  benefits  derived  from  the  expressway  filter 
down to the poor. Benefits from transport cost savings and time savings, along with an increase 
in incomes, will be passed on through the transport chain to townships and villages. These results 
affirm  the  relevance  of  ADB’s  strategy  in  the  PRC  road  sector.  A  TA6 will  help  the  Government 
formulate  a  road  network  strategy  that  better  integrates  expressways  and  local  roads  to  meet 
communities’ needs and support economic growth, and that provides road agencies with cross-
disciplinary skills and tools through capacity building. A case study in Shaanxi Province found that 
improved roads were correlated with poverty reduction, and that (i) 3.2 poor people are lifted out 
of poverty for every CNY10,000 invested in roads; and (ii) for every 1% increase in kilometer of 
road  per  capita,  household  consumption  increases  by  0.08%. 7  Benefits  for  rural  poor  areas 
include  lower  transport  costs;  lower  cost  of  inputs;  expanded  agricultural  support  services; 
improved farming practices; greater access to urban jobs; and better access to health, education, 
and social services.8

The traffic volume on the existing roads in the project area has been increasing at about 
10% per annum in the last 5 years. The roads are already at capacity in certain sections. If the 
new road is not constructed, traffic growth will be suppressed and transport costs will increase. 
Congested  traffic  will  slow  the  project  area’s  economic  growth.  Based  on  the  TA  findings 
(footnote  3),  traffic  volume  on  the  expressway  is  forecast  to  grow  from  10,615  pcu  per  day  in

44. 
To  meet  growing  transport  demand  in  the  project  area,  an  alternative  analysis  reviewed 
various  options  for  transport  modes,  alignments,  technical  designs,  timing  of  investments,  and 
financing modalities as part of the national and provincial transport network plan. The conclusion 
was to improve road transport by constructing an expressway supported by complementary local 
road  improvement.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  was  calculated  by  comparing 
situations with and without the Project. Without the Project, the traffic volume would exceed the 
optimum capacity of the existing National Highway 108, which would become congested, thereby 
increasing  travel  time,  vehicle  operating  costs  (VOCs),  and  the  number  of  accidents.  With  the 
Project,  travel  time  would  be  reduced  by  higher  speeds  and  shorter  distance;  VOCs  would  be 
reduced  by  faster  and  smoother  travel  on  the  expressway;  and  the  accident  rate  would  be 
reduced  by  elimination  of  congestion,  provision  of  safety  features,  and  separation  of  fast-  and 
slow-moving traffic. If local roads are not upgraded, people in the remote parts of the project area 
will  have  less  mobility,  and  the  mainly  poor  inhabitants  will  not  be  able  to  participate  in  the 
mainstream  of  economic  activities.  The  economic  costs  of  the  expressway  reflect  the  resource 
costs for construction, O&M, and the value of agricultural production from land lost permanently. 
The  economic  benefits  generated  by  the  expressway  include  (i) savings  in  VOCs  as  a  result  of 
reduced road length and improved traffic conditions, (ii) time savings for road users, (iii) savings 
from avoided accidents, (iv) benefits from generated traffic, and (v) traffic diversion from rail. The 
benefits from the local roads were estimated from reduced VOCs and producer surplus (the value 
of additional production minus production costs). 
 
The project EIRR is estimated at 15.2%, indicating that the Project is economically viable 
45. 
(Appendix 12).  Results  of  sensitivity  analysis  confirm  the  robustness  of  the  Project's  economic 
viability. Changes in the key variables, such as a 10% reduction in benefits, do not significantly 
impact on economic viability. The capital cost would have to increase by 61% from the estimate 
for the EIRR to fall below the cutoff rate of 12%. The benefit level would have to decrease by 38% 
to  achieve  the  same  effect.  In  light  of  experience  in  the  PRC  road  sector,  variations  of  such 
magnitude are unlikely. The EIRR was calculated separately for the expressway (15.2%) and for 
local roads (15.9%). The economic analysis was extended to cover the distribution of project net 
benefits  by  determining  the  project  effects  for  various  beneficiaries,  including  road  users 
(passengers and freight), labor, and the government. Road users will receive the largest share of 
net benefits, accounting for 93% of the total net benefits (Appendix 12).

2. 
The  United  Nations  Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific 
(UNESCAP)  is  promoting  a  transregional  Asian  highway  network,  extending  140,000 km,  of 
which 26,000 km are in the PRC. Road projects funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
are helping develop this network through a total of 13 completed or planned projects comprising

3. 
In 2003, the PRC vehicle fleet totaled 24 million trucks, cars, and buses, and 72 million 
other  motorized  vehicles  (motorcycles  and  agricultural  vehicles).  The  privately  owned  fleet  of 
motor  vehicles  increased  more  than  20  times  during  1985–2003,  from  0.3 million  vehicles  to 
12.0 million.  Despite  the  rapid  increase  in  total vehicles,  there  are  only  about  1.3  vehicles  per 
100  people,  which  is  lower  than  in  other  Asian  countries.  The  PRC’s  accession  to  the  World 
Trade Organization has increased investment in the automobile industry, reduced the tariffs on 
imported vehicles, and contributed to easing motor vehicle financing. These factors, plus rapidly 
growing  urban  incomes,  underpin  the  growth  in  road  traffic.  The  modernization  of  the  vehicle 
fleet  will  improve  vehicle  safety  and  reduce  individual  vehicles’  fuel  consumption  and  their 
emissions.  In  2003,  the  number  of  vehicles  registered  in  Sichuan  was  734,200  passenger 
vehicles and 392,600 freight vehicles. Vehicle ownership in Sichuan is lower than the national 
average.  Privately  owned  vehicles  totaled  670,200.  Road  passenger  traffic  in  Sichuan 
measured in terms of passenger-km of travel grew by more than 33% in 2000–2003, reaching 
47.7 billion passenger-km. Road freight traffic, in ton-km, grew by 35% during the same period.

Road Sector Revenue and Expenditures 

5. 
Expenditures  in  highway  infrastructure  are  financed  from  dedicated  user  charges, 
government  grants,  domestic  bank  loans  and  bonds,  and  foreign  loans  and  investments.  Two 
dedicated  user  charges,  the  road  maintenance  fee  and  vehicle  purchase  fee,  have  provided 
much  of  the  financing  for  the  road  sector.  During  the  Ninth  Five-Year  Plan  of  1996–2000,  the 
road  maintenance  fee  and  vehicle  purchase  fee  provided  53%  and  13%,  respectively,  of  the 
total  road  investments.  Government  grants  provided  2%,  mainly  to  construct  or  improve  rural 
roads  in  poor  areas.  The  rest  was  financed  from  domestic  loans  and  bonds  (9%);  other 
domestic investments, including financing from local governments and state-owned enterprises 
(12%); foreign loans (8%); and foreign direct investment (3%). 
 
6. 
As  part  of  a  tax  reform  to  bring  off-budget  revenue  and  expenditures  within  the 
framework of the national budget, the National People’s Congress amended the Highway Law 
on 31 October 1999, laying the foundation for legislation providing for national taxes to replace 
provincial  and  local  fees.  The  vehicle  purchase  fee  was  replaced  by  the  vehicle  purchase  tax 
effective January 2001, and a fuel tax is being considered to replace the road maintenance fee. 
Based on findings of an ADB-financed TA,2 the fuel tax is likely to improve financing of the road 
sector.  
 
7. 
SPCD  invested  about  CNY16.2  billion  in  the  road  sector  in  2004:  CNY12.9  billion  for 
construction and CNY1.4 billion for maintenance. During the 10th Five-Year Plan (2001–2005), 
total investment is expected to be about CNY71 billion, with an annual average growth rate of 
5.0%  during  this  period.  SPCD  plans  to  increase  road  investment  to  CNY78  billion  during  the 
11th Five-Year Plan. 
 
E. 
 
8. 
Road  projects  are  designed  by  planning  and  design  institutes  at  the  provincial, 
prefecture, and county levels. MOC reviews the designs of expressways, high-standard roads, 
and  associated  structures.  Design  institutes  are  staffed  with  experienced,  well-qualified 
personnel. The city and county highway bureaus have their own construction units to carry out 
minor  projects  within  their  administrative  districts.  Drawing  on  the  experience  gained  under 
ADB-  and  World  Bank-financed  projects,  competitive  bidding  practices  were  mandated  by  the 
1999 Tendering and Bidding Law.3 Many of the largest provincial and urban construction units 
are being reorganized into financially independent companies and have been awarded contracts 
individually or as partners in joint ventures on several ADB- and World Bank-financed in-country 
or overseas projects.

Road Transport Services 

11. 
A relaxation of trucking regulations in the 1980s allowed privately owned trucks to haul 
cargo for state-owned factories and cooperatives. Privately owned trucks expanded their market 
share during the 1990s at the expense of state-owned transport companies, many of which are 
now  being  privatized.  The  competition  improves  road  transport  efficiency  and  service  quality. 
MOC  is  encouraging  the  private  sector  to  augment  the  overall  capacity  of  the  road  transport 
industry. More small freight operators will merge and more large state-owned companies will be 
privatized.

RURAL ROAD DEVELOPMENT AND LOCAL ROAD COMPONENT  

 
1. 
The rural road forms the basic element of the national road network and provides basic 
access  to  rural  populations.  The  Government  invests  about  CNY20  billion  in  rural  road 
development  annually,  compared  with  only  CNY1  billion–2  billion  annually  before  2003.  Total 
mileage  of  newly  built  rural  road  every  year  is  about  50,000  kilometers  (km)  and  that  of 
reconstruction is about 150,000 km. In 2004, total mileage of rural road reached 1.42 million km. 
The  Government  built  102,000  km  of  rural  roads  in  2003,  and  250,000  km  in  2004,  building 
about  192,000  km  of  paved  rural  roads.  In  2004,  along  with  building  roads  connecting  to  123 
townships  and  11,200  villages,  the  Government  built  paved  roads  connecting  to  1,690 
townships and 57,500 villages. 
 
2. 
The  State  Council  approved  the  Rural  Road  Development  Plan  in  February  2005. The 
overall objective of the plan aimed at 2020 is that the townships and villages will be accessible 
to paved roads, forming a rural road network with high service level, making travel more rapid, 
safe,  and  comfortable  for  farmers. The  development  goal  is  that  by  2010,  all  townships  in  the 
People’s  Republic  of  China  will  be  connected  to  paved  roads  and  all  villages  in  eastern  and 
central regions will be connected to paved roads by 2010. In 2010, total mileage of rural roads 
will be 3.1 million km. This is expected to increase to 3.7 million km by 2020, improving density 
and service level of rural roads. 
 
3. 
The  project  expressway  is  supported  by  the  local  road  component,  thereby  improving 
access  to  townships  and  villages  in  the  project  area.  By  lowering  transport  costs  and  travel 
times, the Project will foster trade, economic development, growth, and incomes in the region. In 
doing so, it will help reduce the prices of daily necessities in local markets and villages served 
by its interchanges and improve access to external markets, information, services, and income-
earning  opportunities.  These  benefits  will  be  increased  and  more  widely  distributed  by 
integrating the 678 km of local road upgrading to the project design (Tables A5.1 and A5.2). The 
importance of improving local roads is in line with the Government’s policies. According to the 
Rural  Poverty  Reduction  Development  Outline,  road  construction  projects  will  be  extended  to 
poor areas to link their townships to national and provincial trunk roads. 
 
Under the technical assistance,1 the local road component was formulated based on the 
4. 
following principles: (i) it will explicitly target the improvement of access to poor townships and 
villages and connecting them to the national and provincial road network in the project area, (ii) 
the  prime  emphasis  will  be  on  providing  all-weather  access  to  the  remaining  centers  and

TRANSPORT SERVICES IN THE PROJECT AREA 

Passenger Transport 

 
A. 
 
The bus transport industry is regulated by the transport administration bureaus (TABs) at 
1. 
the provincial, prefecture, and county levels. All bus operators need an operating license and all 
buses have to be licensed for a specific route. The TAB may, in principle, grant licenses to more 
than  one  operator  on  the  same  route,  Yingjing  county,  however,  has  only  one  licensed  bus 
operator.  Fares  for  journeys  terminating  at  townships  or  larger  towns  are  regulated  by  the 
provincial price bureau. Fares for township to village journeys are not regulated.  
 
2. 
A  relatively  dense  network  of  bus  routes  connects  almost  all  the  townships  in  the 
province, serving all the villages on the routes. Nevertheless, many villages with poor or no road 
access  still  have  no  direct  bus  service.  There  are  no  cross-county  routes  that  provide  direct 
connections across township boundaries without going through township centers.  
 
The  government  is  encouraging  private  involvement  in  the  transport  sector.  State 
3. 
companies are now being sold off. Regulated fares are only a little higher than financial vehicle 
operating costs per passenger for mini-buses operating on township and village roads, but that 
net  margins  for  medium  buses  on  good  roads  are  attractive.  Bus  operators  report  that  their 
businesses are profitable, especially the longer-distance services.   
 
4. 
The  TABs  control  the  number  of  operators  on  each  route  in  order  to  prevent  “over-
supply,”  while  the  number  of  trips  per  day  carried  out  by  each  operator  is  controlled,  either 
through operator associations or directly by state-owned bus terminal companies, which control 
the bus schedule and allocate slots to operators. It would appear that these restrictive operating 
practices  result  in  low  vehicle  utilization  and,  as  a  consequence,  unnecessarily  high  operating 
costs.  
 
5. 
In  the  project  area,  although  the  number  of  buses  in  operation  has  substantially 
increased,  this  is  mainly  accounted  for  by  a  shift  towards  smaller  buses.    The  majority  of 
licensees are individuals; the number of company licensees has fallen significantly since 1997 
and  now  only  represents  12%  of  the  total.   Total  passenger  volumes  in  the  project  area  have 
increased by 60% since 1997, although passenger-kilometers have only increased by 40%.

6. 
Any commercial trucking operation requires a license, which is issued by the prefecture 
TAB.  Own-account  trucking  (for  the  transport  of  goods  within  the  same  enterprise)  does  not 
need  a  TAB  license.  Operators  must  meet  basic  requirements  on  financial  resources  and 
maintenance  capacity.    The  licenses  are  of  indefinite  duration  and  a  small  fee  is  payable  on 
initial licensing and for the annual vehicle inspections.  There is no annual license fee.  
 
7. 
The  Ministry  of  Communications  publishes  guidelines  on  freight  rates  but  truckers  are 
not obliged to follow them.  In practice, rates are negotiated between the shipper and the trucker 
and are normally much lower than the guidelines.

TRAFFIC FORECAST 

 
1. 
The Project Expressway is the final section of the Chengdu–Panzhihua Highway, one of 
eight  important  highways  planned  for  implementation  of  the  Western  Region  Development 
Strategy and one of the key national roads, the Lanzhou (Gansu Province) to Muhan (Yunnan 
Province)  highway,  and  is  also  one  of  the  sections  of  the  proposed  Sichuan  Provincial 
Expressway  Network.  With  completion  of  this  Project,  the  Chengdu–Panzhihua  Corridor  will 
become  a  major  artery  for  the  regional  transport  network,  connecting  with  national  and 
provincial roads. 
 
2. 
The project expressway will be built in parallel to an existing class-II national road (NR 
108)  that  has  a  pavement  in  poor  condition  over  many  sections,  suffers  from  winter  icing  and 
snow  in  the  higher  elevations,  has  poor  horizontal  and  vertical  alignment  and  already  suffers 
some congestion and interference from local and nonmotorized traffic. The expressway will link 
up  in  Lugu  with  the  ongoing  Asian  Development  Bank-financed  Southern  Sichuan  Road 
Development Project and provide efficient and safe road transport in central Sichuan. 
 
3. 
Traffic  surveys  were  carried  out  under  the  feasibility  study.  Sixteen-hour  origin-
destination (O-D) surveys and associated 24-hour classified traffic counts were done at 15 key 
locations  along  the  existing  NR108  and  linking  roads.  The  surveys  were  carried  out  in  April 
2000. The expressway starts just south of the city of Ya’an. The highest flows are just south of 
Ya’an  with  the  low  flows  in  the  mountainous  sparsely  populated  area  between  Yingjing  and 
Hanyuan counties. The proportion of trucks is typically more than half, but ranges from 21% to 
73%. Over all traffic survey stations, the feasibility study recorded 62% trucks, mainly light and 
medium-sized ones in about equal proportions. 
 
4. 
The  evaluation  of  alternative  options  in  the  project  corridor—i.e.,  with  and  without  the 
proposed  expressway—has  been  carried  out  using  the  feasibility  traffic  demand  OD  matrices 
and  assigning  these  flows  over  the  road  networks  expected  to  in  2000  (the  base  year),  2011, 
2020, and 2030. For each link in this network, the length, pavement width, surface type, terrain, 
estimated pavement roughness, and available traffic counts were entered into the network data 
files to assist with validation of the matrices and traffic assignments.  
 
5. 
Vehicle speeds are affected by terrain and the degree of congestion, in turn a function of 
the  capacity  of  the  link.  Estimates  of  road  capacity  were  based  on  the  revised  the  Ministry  of 
Communication’s Technical Standards for Highway Engineering. An initial free-flow speed was 
defined for each road link, used in estimating initial link travel times. As link loadings increase 
and links become more congested, these times increase and link speeds reduce. The revised 
speeds are adjusted using speed-flow relationships, also used in calculating user costs on links 
for the economic evaluation. The relationships have been updated to take account of the hourly 
distribution of traffic volumes and the vehicle mix in the corridor. 
 
6. 
Forecast  passenger  and  freight  vehicle  OD  matrices  for  2011,  2020,  and  2030  were 
developed from the 2000 base-year matrices by applying projections of regional gross domestic 
product  (GDP)  and  estimates  of  elasticities  of  transport  demand  with  respect  to  GDP  growth. 
Based  on  a  comparison  of  trends  in  GDP  and  alternative  measures  of  transport  demand—
passenger  vehicles  and  trucks  registered,  total  passengers  and  tons  moved,  and  estimated 
passenger-km  and  ton-km  in  other  developed  and  undeveloped  provinces,  the  following 
demand elasticities were adopted: passenger trips 1.2, freight trips 0.8. 
 
7. 
The  forecast  GDP  growth  rates  were  applied  to  the  calibrated  base-year  matrices  to 
produce  interzonal  passenger  and  freight  vehicle  flows  for  2011,  2020,  and  2030,  which  were

assigned  to  the  without-project  road  network  for  the  base  year  and  each  forecast  year.  Non-
modeled (intrazonal) traffic was preloaded to the appropriate network links.  
 
8. 
By  2010,  the  traffic  on  the  existing  NR108  will  reach  capacity  at  several  points, 
particularly near Yuchen, and by 2020 it will be well over capacity along its whole route. Rather 
than  have  an  increasing  proportion  of  traffic  artificially  divert  to  much  longer  alternative  routes 
via  other  corridors,  the  capacity  of  NR108  has  been  increased  to  reflect  a  more  realistic 
scenario  of  incremental  widening  at  the  most  congested  points.  This  was  done  for  certain 
sections in 2011, and again in 2020, when congestion will have worsened further. 
 
9. 
Road vehicles moving from one zone to another choose between alternative routes on 
the basis of their perceptions of generalized travel cost, a function of travel time, distance, and 
toll cost. Given the significant improvements in terms of the performance and efficiency of the 
Ya’an–Lugu corridor as a result of the Project Expressway, it will attract significant vehicle trips 
(especially through trips) from other roads, and this will reduce the number of accidents, vehicle 
operating  costs  (VOCs),  and  travel  time  on  many  roads  in  the  corridor  and  thereby  directly 
benefit the project area. 
 
10.  When  the  expressway  is  built,  it  will  become  a  more  attractive  alternative  route  for 
people and goods traveling along the corridor, particularly for those traveling long distances by 
rail. At present, the railway carries most of the long-distance bulk traffic in the project corridor. 
When  the  expressway  opens,  some  of  the  passengers  and  freight  using  rail  will  start  using  it. 
The completed expressway from Chengdu to Panzhihua will reduce the driving distance to 610 
km. This compares with a rail distance of 749 km. Express passenger trains cover the journey at 
an average of 60 km/h, while the slower services travel at 50 km/h. Passengers will save about 
5 hours if they divert from rail to road.  
 
11. 
Traffic  forecast  was  determined  based  on  socioeconomic  trends  that  took  into  account 
changes in variables such as gross domestic product, population, and vehicle ownership. The 
forecast traffic volume on the expressway is expected to grow from 10,615 passenger car units 
(pcu) in 2011 to 20,495 pcu in 2021, a 6.8% average annual growth rate. It will then grow more 
slowly at 5.8% per annum thereafter to reach 34,043 pcu in 2030. Through traffic will be about 
40%  of  the  total.  The  traffic  on  the  local  roads  will  grow  more  slowly  because  of  slow  growth 
prospects in the project area.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

 
1. 
The project expressway traverses central Sichuan Province. Local roads are connected 
to  the  expressway  through  the  road  network  system.  The  economic  analysis  covers  the  26 
years of construction and operation. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of the Project 
was  estimated  by  comparing  the  situation  with  and  without  the  Project.  Without  the  Project, 
traffic will use the existing road network, which will be congested and expensive to maintain due 
to  the  rapidly  increasing  volume  of  traffic.  Some  travel  may  not  take  place  because  of  the 
congestion and  the  resulting  increasing  travel  times  and  vehicle  operating  costs  (VOCs).  With 
the Project, congestion on the existing roads will be reduced, and traffic on the expressway and 
the  existing  roads  will  benefit  from  faster,  cheaper,  and  safer  travel.  Additional  trips  will  be 
generated as the economy responds to lower transport costs and better service. 
 
2. 
Alternative  Analysis.  As  part  of  economic  analysis,  possible  alternative  interventions 
were  considered  to  meet  the  growing  transport  demand  in  the  project  area  as  part  of  the 
national and provincial transport network plan. Alternative analysis reviewed various options in 
terms  of  transport  modes,  alignments,  technical  designs,  timing  of  investments,  and  financing 
modalities. While  enhancing  the  existing  railway  capacity  may  be  an  option  to  partly  meet  the 
increasing  demand,  it  will  not  completely  satisfy  the  various  kinds  of  traffic,  particularly  high-
value general cargo that requires a more flexible and responsive mode to meet the needs of a 
market  economy.  Six  alternative  alignments  were  reviewed  based  on  geologic  and 
topographical conditions, terrain considerations, consultations with community representatives, 
cost  estimates,  relative  impacts  on  environment  and  resettlement,  and  integration  with  the 
national  and  local  transport  network.  The  expressway  technical  design  was  proposed  after 
consideration  of  the  national  highway  network,  consistency  in  the  standards  of  contiguous 
sections  at  each  end  of  the  project  expressway,  and  forecast  traffic.  Alternative  financing 
modalities  were  considered,  including  private  sector  investment.  However,  private  sector 
investment was not found attractive due to risks associated with construction and low estimated 
rates of return. Hence, public financing was considered appropriate. 
 
3. 
General  Parameters.  Economic  evaluation  was  undertaken  using  constant  2005 
economic prices. The prices are expressed in yuan using the domestic price numeraire, with a 
shadow exchange rate factor of 1.013 for foreign exchange effects. A shadow price was used to 
place  an  economic  value  on  the  wages  paid  to  unskilled  labor,  while  skilled  labor  was  not 
shadow priced since there is no surplus of skilled workers. A shadow wage rate factor of 0.67 
was used to convert the financial wage rate to an economic opportunity cost of labor. 
 
4. 
Costs.  The  capital  costs  and  physical  contingencies  for  the  Project  are  revalued  at 
economic  prices  by  separating  the  cost  items  into  tradable  materials  and  equipment, 
nontradable  materials,  labor,  and  land.  The  land  and  resettlement  costs  were  based  on  their 
opportunity costs, i.e., agricultural output forgone and re-siting of displaced activities. 
 
5. 
Benefits. The economic benefits include (i) savings in VOCs resulting from the reduced 
travel distance and improved road conditions, (ii) savings in the value of passenger time and of 
freight  tied  up  in  transit,  (iii) savings  resulting  from  fewer  accidents,  (iv) benefits  to  generated 
traffic,  and  (v) savings  in  capital  and  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs  for  National 
Highway (NH) 108. A reduction in VOCs is the main source of economic benefits for the Project. 
Traffic diverting to the expressway would travel at high, more economical speeds on a smoother 
road,  with  better  vertical  and  horizontal  alignment,  less  congestion,  and  a  shorter  journey 
distance. Traffic remaining on the alternative NH108 route would also benefit from a reduction in 
traffic volume and congestion. All these changes affect vehicle speeds and VOCs, which were

estimated for all vehicle types likely to use the corridor. Savings in travel time will be seen both 
on  the  project  expressway  and  the  existing  roads.  Work-related  travel  time  was  evaluated  for 
private  vehicles  and  buses.  The  economic  cost  of  accidents  was  estimated  on  direct  property 
damage and foregone income. 
 
6. 
Six  hundred  seventy-eight  km  of  local  roads  will  be  improved  concurrently  with  the 
expressway component. The costs of this component include capital costs and O&M costs. The 
principal  benefits  of  the  local  road  improvements  were  identified  as  reduced  VOCs  and  the 
producer  surplus  (the  value  of  additional  production  minus  production  costs).  Transport  cost 
savings will accrue to normal traffic on the improved roads. The local roads recommended for 
upgrading  were  chosen  based  on  poverty  incidence,  the  effect  on  overall  road  network 
efficiency, economic development potential, and population density. 
 
7. 
Result  and  Conclusion.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  for  the  Project, 
including the expressway and local road components, is 15.2% (Table A12.1). The EIRR for the 
expressway component alone is 15.2%, and for the local road component, 15.9%. VOC savings 
are  the  major  economic  benefit  (78%),  followed  by  travel  time  savings  (13%),  local  road 
component (3%), and accident cost savings (3%). 
 
8. 
The results of the sensitivity analysis confirm the robustness of the Project’s economic 
viability:  changes  in  the  key  variables—construction  costs,  benefits,  traffic  growth,  residual 
value, and 1-year delay in completion—do not significantly affect the economic viability (Table 
A12.2). The capital cost would have to be 61% higher than estimated for the EIRR to fall below 
the  cutoff  rate  of  12%.  Considering  the  experience  of  ADB  in  the  PRC,  such  an  increase  in 
capital cost is unlikely. ADB-financed road projects in the PRC have not encountered major cost 
overruns,  and  the  contract  prices  tend  to  be  lower  than  estimated  because  the  contracting 
process  is  becoming  increasingly  competitive.  The  benefit  level  would  have  to  decrease  more 
than  38%  to  make  the  Project  economically  nonviable.  A  risk  analysis  was  carried  out  to 
determine  the  degree  of  uncertainty  on  the  Project.  Each  uncertainty  factor  (such  as  capital 
cost, traffic growth, and VOC value) was varied at random within the limits. The results showed 
that an EIRR exceeding 12% will be achieved with a 95% probability. The economic analysis of 
the  Project  was  extended  to  analyze  distribution  of  project  net  benefits  by  determining  the 
project effects for various beneficiaries, including road users (passenger and freight), labor, and 
government. It was found that road users will receive the largest share of net benefit, accounting 
for 93% of the total net benefits (Table A12.3).

D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
There are gender differences in the division of labor as in many other regions. Men are mainly employed in 
outside and heavy physical activities and as migrant workers, while women are responsible for household 
chores  and  cropping  activities.  Women’s  role  in  household  and  community  decision  making  varies  from 
place to place and is improving although still limited. Of all the women surveyed, 85%, 2%, and 13%, felt 
satisfied,  unsatisfied  and  unclear,  respectively,  about  their  current  status.  As  in  other  parts  of  the  PRC, 
urban  and  roadside  communities  have  less  obvious  differences  between  women  and  men  in  division  of 
labor and decision making. Therefore the project, especially the local roads, will enhance women’s role in 
general. As part of the participation strategy, priority will be given to women for direct and indirect project 
benefits,  which  are  included  in  the  ethnic  minority  development  plan  (EMDP)  and  SDAP.  Gender

SUMMARY ETHNIC MINORITIES DEVELOPMENT PLAN 

 
1. 
An  ethnic  minorities  development  plan  (EMDP)  was  prepared  to  ensure  equitable 
sharing of project benefits by implementing mitigation measures for adverse impacts on minority 
communities  in  the  project  area.  A  full  EMDP  is  available  in  Supplementary  Appendix  K.  The 
EMDP is based on the resettlement plan, the social and poverty assessment, and consultation 
with  ethnic  minority  groups,  and  local  county  governments  and  their  line  agencies.  This  plan 
primarily  targets  the  project-affected  Yi  minority,  who  account  for  about  86%  (138,000)  of  the 
total minority population.  
 
2. 
The  Yi  are  the  poorest  in  the  project  area.  A  field  survey  indicated  that  (i)  the  poverty 
incidence  (average  per  capita  annual  income  of  under  CNY900)  among  the  surveyed  Yi 
communities is 45%, while it is 17% for the Han; (ii) the average per capita annual income of the 
surveyed  Yi  villages  is  CNY975,  while  it  is  CNY1,450  for  the  Han;  and  (iii)  only  4%  of  Yi 
households have a motor vehicle, compared to 28% for the Han. The education level for the Yi 
is lower than for the Han. The adult illiteracy rate of the Yi, for instance, is as high as 35%, while 
that of the Han is 5%. Migration to local mines and construction sites is common for both the Yi 
and Han in recent years. However, the Han also seek migration work in other regions while the 
Yi do not. While the Han migrate from rural to major urban areas to find off-farm jobs, they are 
unlikely  to  migrate  to  the  project  area  because  it  has  no  new  permanent  jobs,  only  temporary 
jobs in road construction. The project area is an area of narrow corridors and high mountains, 
with no potential for large-scale industrial development. Population growth during 1995–2000 in 
the project area was 0.06% to 1.53%. No HIV/AIDS1 cases were reported in the project counties. 
Around 24,400 expressway construction workers will go to the project area and will interact with 
local  minority  population,  increasing  its  risk  of  exposure  to  HIV/AIDS  and  sexually  transmitted 
infections.

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN 

1. 
The proposed Project will finance the construction of an expressway between Ya’an and 
Lugu,  with  a  length  of  244  kilometers  (km),  and  a  local  road  component  with  a  total  length  of 
678  km  county  to  township  and  township  to  village  roads.  The  resettlement  plan1 covers  both 
components  based  on  the  feasibility  study.  The  proposed  Yalu  expressway  (including 
connecting  roads)  will  affect  29  townships  and  93  administrative  villages  in  five  counties: 
Yucheng,  Yingjing,  Hanyuan,  and  Shimian  in  Ya’an  municipality;  and  Mianning  in  Liangshan 
Prefecture.  The  local  road  program  involves  upgrading  the  existing  county  to  township  and 
township to village roads, so it is not expected to involve a significant amount of land acquisition 
and  resettlement.  The  resettlement  plan  will  be  revised  after  completion  of  the  preliminary 
design,  including  village  rehabilitation  plans,  and  submitted  to  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB) for approval prior to commencement of land acquisition. 

2. 
For the expressway, 1,466 hectares (ha) will be permanently acquired, of which 21% is 
paddy,  35%  dryland,  15%  orchard,  15%  forestland,  1%  housing  plots,  and  13%  wasteland. 
Another  347.6  ha  will  be  occupied  temporarily  during  construction.  Based  on  per  capita 
farmland  in  affected  villages,  farmland  acquisition  will  be  equivalent  to  20,237  people  (5,711 
households)  losing  all  their  farmland.  It  is  expected  that  the  average  loss  of  farmland  per 
household  will  be  25%;  94,800  square  meters  (m2)  of  houses  will  be  demolished,  requiring 
relocation of 790 households (2,634 people). About 70% of houses are made of brick and wood, 
and earth and wood, and 30% are brick and concrete. Most of these households will be moved 
a  short  distance  within  their  original  village.  All  land,  housing,  and  other  assets  will  be 
compensated at replacement value.  

3. 
For people unavoidably affected, the resettlement objective is to achieve equal or better 
income  and  living  standards  in  line  with  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  Land 
Administration  Law  (1998)  and  the  ADB’s  policy  on  involuntary  resettlement.  The  Sichuan 
Provincial  Communications  Department  (SPCD)  will  ensure  that  any  people  losing  land, 
housing, other assets, or income sources will be assisted to fully restore their income and living 
standards.  A  comprehensive  compensation  rate  (for  land  compensation,  resettlement  subsidy, 
and cost of young crops) has been estimated at CNY480,000 per ha for irrigated farmland, and 
CNY300,000 per ha for dry land. Those losing land temporarily during construction will receive a 
payment equivalent to production value foregone for the period of loss, which is expected to be 
2  years.  The  land  used  temporarily  will  also  be  restored  by  the  contractor  to  the  original 
condition.  For  structures  to  be  demolished,  replacement  value  will  be  provided  to  the  affected 
households based on compensation rates adopted in affected city and prefecture, which range 
from CNY350 to CNY450/m2 for brick and concrete structures, CNY280 to CNY340/m2 for brick-
wood  structure,  and  CNY220  to  CNY260/m2  for  earth  and  wood  structures.  Those  losing 
housing will be compensated for their housing plot, equivalent to the rate for irrigated farmland, 
so  they  can  acquire  new  housing  sites  close  to  a  road  and  with  electricity  and  water  in  their 
village  group  or  administrative  village.  Housing  compensation  will  not  be  reduced  for 
depreciation,  and  people  will  be  allowed  to  salvage  materials  from  their  old  houses.  Efforts  to 
minimize resettlement effects have been made after consultations with local officials during the 
setting  of  the  alignment  for  the  feasibility  study  to  avoid  towns,  villages,  and  high-yield  paddy 
and fruit gardens.  

4.

acquisition  will  have  significant  impact  on  the  income  and  livelihood  of  the  project-affected
